Award.AwardTitle: On Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon Molecules in Comets
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is comprised of theoretical studies of the excitation, alteration, and destruction of the class of large organic molecules known as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). These molecules are detected by their characteristic spectra in observations of the interstellar medium (ISM) in our own Milky Way and other galaxies. Logically, they would have been present in the original material that formed our Solar System. But the fragility of PAH molecules implies that they would not have been expected to survive in Solar System bodies, except possibly in comets. Detecting PAHs in comets would establish an important chemical link between the ISM and the Solar System. PAHs have not been unambiguously detected in the observed infrared spectra of comets, in part because the expected infrared emission spectra and destruction rates of PAHs in cometary environments are not adequately understood. This is the problem that the proposal aims to address. The Principal Investigator and a supported graduate student will study the photoexcitation, photoionization, and photodissociation of PAH molecules and their ions in cometary comae illuminated by the Sun. They will calculate, using numerical statistical mechanics techniques, the emission spectra and destruction rates of 23 representative specific PAH molecules and their ions, as well as three nitrogen-substituted PAHs appropriate to nitrogen-rich comets and generic "astro-PAH" models approximating the interstellar species. The goal is to create a web-based "library" of the emission spectra and photodissociation and photoionization rates of PAH molecules as a function of distance from the Sun. By comparing observed cometary spectra the model spectra from the library, researchers will be able to constrain PAH production and destruction rates and interpret observational detections and non-detections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) molecules are a significant constituent of the matter in the space between stars which is known as ``the interstellar medium''. They might have been incorporated into comets during the formation of the solar system because comets are the most pristine bodies in the solar system and could have preserved the presolar interstellar materials out of which the solar system formed 4.9 billion years ago. However, the characterstic spectral features of PAHs ubiquitously seen in a wide range of interstellar regions in the Milky Way and other galaxies as well as in planet-forming dust disks are rather weak or absent in comets, while small PAH molecules have been detected in the cometary dust sample brought back to Earth from comet 81P/Wild 2 by the Stardust space mission. Supported by this NSF/AST grant, we carefully examined the physical and chemical processes of over 20 specific PAH molecular species in cometary comae. These molecules are exposed to the solar ultraviolet (UV) radiation and could be dissociated and therefore do not emit much energy in the characteristic spectral bands. We calculated the photodestruction rates of cometary PAHs and indeed find they are indeed radpidly destroyed by UV photons in several seconds. We also calculated the emission spectra of PAHs in cometary comae at a range of distances from the Sun and compared with the observed emission spectra of a number of comets. We found that the PAH abundance (relative to dust grains) of comets is similar to that of planet-forming disks, much lower than that of the ISM. Through this grant, two graduate students and two undergradate students were supported and trained.
